column3: May I go with you? asked Dorothy, eagerly.

column2: Of course, my dear Princess; and I also invite any of our friends here who would like to undertake the journey.
column3: Of course, my dear Princess; and I also invite any of our friends here who would like to undertake the journey.

column2: They all declared they wished to accompany their girl Ruler, for this was indeed an important mission, since the future of the Land of Oz to a great extent depended upon it.
column3: They all declared they wished to accompany their girl Ruler, for this was indeed an important mission, since the future of the Land of Oz to a great extent depended upon it.

column2: So Ozma gave orders to her servants to prepare for the journey on the morrow.
column3: So Ozma gave orders to her servants to prepare for the journey on the morrow.

column2: That day she watched her Magic Picture, and when it showed her that all the Nomes had returned through the tunnel to their underground caverns,
column3: That day she watched her Magic Picture, and when it showed her that all the Nomes had returned through the tunnel to their underground caverns,

column2: Ozma used the Magic Belt to close up the tunnel, so that the earth underneath the desert sands became as solid as it was before the Nomes began to dig.
column3: Ozma used the Magic Belt to close up the tunnel, so that the earth underneath the desert sands became as solid as it was before the Nomes began to dig.

column2: Early the following morning a gay cavalcade set out to visit the famous Sorceress, Glinda the Good. Ozma and Dorothy rode in a chariot drawn by the Cowardly Lion and the Hungry Tiger,
column3: Early the following morning a gay cavalcade set out to visit the famous Sorceress, Glinda the Good. Ozma and Dorothy rode in a chariot drawn by the Cowardly Lion and the Hungry Tiger,

column2: while the Sawhorse drew the red wagon in which rode the rest of the party.
column3: while the Sawhorse drew the red wagon in which rode the rest of the party.

column2: With hearts light and free from care they traveled merrily along through the lovely and fascinating Land of Oz, and in good season reached the stately castle in which resided the Sorceress.
column3: With hearts light and free from care they traveled merrily along through the lovely and fascinating Land of Oz, and in good season reached the stately castle in which resided the Sorceress.

column2: Glinda knew that they were coming.
column3: Glinda knew that they were coming.

column2: I have been reading about you in my Magic Book, she said, as she greeted them in her gracious way.
column3: I have been reading about you in my Magic Book, she said, as she greeted them in her gracious way.

column2: What is your Magic Book like? inquired Aunt Em, curiously.
column3: What is your Magic Book like? inquired Aunt Em, curiously.

column2: It is a record of everything that happens, replied the Sorceress.
column3: It is a record of everything that happens, replied the Sorceress.

column2: As soon as an event takes place, anywhere in the world, it is immediately found printed in my Magic Book. So when I read its pages I am well informed.
column3: As soon as an event takes place, anywhere in the world, it is immediately found printed in my Magic Book. So when I read its pages I am well informed.

column2: Did it tell you how our enemies drank the Water of 'Blivion? asked Dorothy.
column3: Did it tell you how our enemies drank the Water of 'Blivion? asked Dorothy.

column2: Yes, my dear; it told all about it. And also it told me you were all coming to my castle, and why.
column3: Yes, my dear; it told all about it. And also it told me you were all coming to my castle, and why.

column2: Then, said Ozma, I suppose you know what is in my mind, and that I am seeking a way to prevent any one in the future from discovering the Land of Oz.
column3: Then, said Ozma, I suppose you know what is in my mind, and that I am seeking a way to prevent any one in the future from discovering the Land of Oz.

column2: Yes; I know that. And while you were on your journey I have thought of a way to accomplish your desire. For it seems to me unwise to allow too many outside people to come here.
column3: Yes; I know that. And while you were on your journey I have thought of a way to accomplish your desire. For it seems to me unwise to allow too many outside people to come here.

column2: Dorothy, with her uncle and aunt, has now returned to Oz to live always, and there is no reason why we should leave any way open for others to travel uninvited to our fairyland.
column3: Dorothy, with her uncle and aunt, has now returned to Oz to live always, and there is no reason why we should leave any way open for others to travel uninvited to our fairyland.

column2: Let us make it impossible for any one ever to communicate with us in any way, after this. Then we may live peacefully and contentedly.
column3: Let us make it impossible for any one ever to communicate with us in any way, after this. Then we may live peacefully and contentedly.

column2: Your advice is wise, returned Ozma. I thank you, Glinda, for your promise to assist me.
column3: Your advice is wise, returned Ozma. I thank you, Glinda, for your promise to assist me.

column2: But how can you do it? asked Dorothy. How can you keep every one from ever finding Oz?
column3: But how can you do it? asked Dorothy. How can you keep every one from ever finding Oz?

column2: By making our country invisible to all eyes but our own, replied the Sorceress, smiling. I have a magic charm powerful enough to accomplish that wonderful feat,
column3: By making our country invisible to all eyes but our own, replied the Sorceress, smiling. I have a magic charm powerful enough to accomplish that wonderful feat,

column2: and now that we have been warned of our danger by the Nome King's invasion, I believe we must not hesitate to separate ourselves forever from all the rest of the world.
column3: and now that we have been warned of our danger by the Nome King's invasion, I believe we must not hesitate to separate ourselves forever from all the rest of the world.

column2: I agree with you, said the Ruler of Oz.
column3: I agree with you, said the Ruler of Oz.

column2: Won't it make any difference to us? asked Dorothy, doubtfully.
column3: Won't it make any difference to us? asked Dorothy, doubtfully.

column2: No, my dear, Glinda answered, assuringly. We shall still be able to see each other and everything in the Land of Oz. It won't affect us at all;
column3: No, my dear, Glinda answered, assuringly. We shall still be able to see each other and everything in the Land of Oz. It won't affect us at all;

column2: but those who fly through the air over our country will look down and see nothing at all.
column3: but those who fly through the air over our country will look down and see nothing at all.

column2: Those who come to the edge of the desert, or try to cross it, will catch no glimpse of Oz, or know in what direction it lies.
column3: Those who come to the edge of the desert, or try to cross it, will catch no glimpse of Oz, or know in what direction it lies.

column2: No one will try to tunnel to us again because we cannot be seen and therefore cannot be found.
column3: No one will try to tunnel to us again because we cannot be seen and therefore cannot be found.

column2: In other words, the Land of Oz will entirely disappear from the knowledge of the rest of the world.
column3: In other words, the Land of Oz will entirely disappear from the knowledge of the rest of the world.

column2: That's all right, said Dorothy, cheerfully. You may make Oz invis'ble as soon as you please, for all I care.
column3: That's all right, said Dorothy, cheerfully. You may make Oz invis'ble as soon as you please, for all I care.

column2: It is already invisible, Glinda stated. I knew Ozma's wishes, and performed the Magic Spell before you arrived.
column3: It is already invisible, Glinda stated. I knew Ozma's wishes, and performed the Magic Spell before you arrived.

column2: Ozma seized the hand of the Sorceress and pressed it gratefully.
column3: Ozma seized the hand of the Sorceress and pressed it gratefully.

column2: Thank you! she said.
column3: Thank you! she said.

column2: End of chapter 29.

column2: The writer of these Oz stories has received a little note from Princess Dorothy of Oz which, for a time, has made him feel rather disconcerted.
column3: The writer of these Oz stories has received a little note from Princess Dorothy of Oz which, for a time, has made him feel rather disconcerted.

column2: The note was written on a broad, white feather from a stork's wing, and it said: YOU WILL NEVER HEAR ANYTHING MORE ABOUT OZ, BECAUSE WE ARE NOW CUT OFF FOREVER FROM ALL THE REST OF THE WORLD.
column3: The note was written on a broad, white feather from a stork's wing, and it said: YOU WILL NEVER HEAR ANYTHING MORE ABOUT OZ, BECAUSE WE ARE NOW CUT OFF FOREVER FROM ALL THE REST OF THE WORLD.

column2: BUT TOTO AND I WILL ALWAYS LOVE YOU AND ALL THE OTHER CHILDREN WHO LOVE US.
column3: BUT TOTO AND I WILL ALWAYS LOVE YOU AND ALL THE OTHER CHILDREN WHO LOVE US.

column2: This seemed to me too bad, at first, for Oz is a very interesting fairyland. Still, we have no right to feel grieved, for we have had enough of the history of the Land of Oz to fill six story books,
column3: This seemed to me too bad, at first, for Oz is a very interesting fairyland. Still, we have no right to feel grieved, for we have had enough of the history of the Land of Oz to fill six story books,

column2: and from its quaint people and their strange adventures we have been able to learn many useful and amusing things.
column3: and from its quaint people and their strange adventures we have been able to learn many useful and amusing things.

column2: So good luck to little Dorothy and her companions. May they live long in their invisible country and be very happy!
column3: So good luck to little Dorothy and her companions. May they live long in their invisible country and be very happy!
